comment: Better performance. Pulp Mill shows a path forward this this approach.
More insight
More options
Easier deployment of games for sideloading.
Active development
A larger map system like in Bitsy to make exit management easier, and the ability to see adjacent rooms in the player centered camera for larger than screen worlds.
something a little more explicitly ECS, like being able to define a script as a separate entity and assign it to a game object.
Conversion to the SDK for growing projects
Envelope Control for the Sound/Music editor
Bugfixes and feature updates
better tile management/organization and a way to detect held buttons
resource image editor for regular dev
Video tutorials
Full playdate screen resolution support
More options for sound and songs (volume adjustments, voice muting...)
Break from tile format and allow HyperCard-style development
More traditional programming constructs, like arrays, for loops and such
More detailed tiles

I Have A List Of Specific Things, As Should Anyone
But I Don't Want To See It Become Extremely Powerful
I Love The Simplistic Nature And Ease Of Learning That Comes With Pulp Development
It's Not As Powerful As The SDK, But That's The Point Yk?
Looking Through Feature Requests On The Forum And Using Those To Make Development *Easier* Would Be Good
But Keeping Pulp Beginner-Friendly Should Be The Main Focus Other Than Adding Things To It Until "Why Even Use The SDK"

But I Mean I Don't Develop That Stuff Idk Also More Customization Like Animations Playing While Say Command Happens Or Restricting Player Movement That'd Be Good I Hear Complaints About That Including From Myself
Multi-tile importing and management features
Support for compound operators and/or array
Bug fixes and while I'm in the middle of coding, clicking anywhere outside of the text box will bring up an annoying window. I would like a way to toggle that off.
More pixels, better exits, easier save states, menus
Arrays and structs!
More QOL features and better sprite system.
An integrated section to create pixel art that will export without issue.
Higher resolution, different player movement types, a way to organize tiles
More flexibility for action games
More guardrails for bigger games, such as a solution for state management. Pulp makes it very easy to write terrible code.
HD (16x16) tiles
Ability to save full game state (not just individual variables)
Better sorting of sprites
Full resolution, bigger player sprites.
Isometric tiles
variable sprite sizes, X/Y coordinate tweening
Tile management
Access to internet functions and microphone functions
I don't think I was the original target audience for Pulp. I'd love for it to support more complexity and functionality. Some basic things are very hard to achieve at the moment.
Onion skin animation
Full resolution. Non grid sprite movent, text to speech
more flexibility
Smooth character movement
Tile management/organization
Bigger sprites! And/or an easy way to link multiple sprites, i.e. for a 4-sprite player character.
Larger sprite and room graphics.
More control of the rooms and more scripting options.
The ability to release web-playable versions to host on itch.io and play in a browser (i.e. a full Bitsy alternative)
Controlling the speed of text and adding sounds as text prints
sprite management and layers
More tutorials
sprite management

Pixel transition , subtile in pixel , bigger sprite possible , basic physic engine for platformer ,
Fx for pulp music editor. Sharable link of pulp game in web.
Array in pulpscript !!! 
Args for a table for function  (like emit myfunc [arg1,arg2]).
But I love this actual version but I thing you could get much more from pulp ;)

Dream of a collaboratif pulp version for working at the sometime on shared project...
Better tile management
I'm very new so any support stuff for new devs is appreciated

I think Pulp is too limited for my game, so I may not be the best judge. However, I think it's a very bizarre decision to limit the games to half resolution. I would get rid of that arbitrary limitation as soon as possible. I also think that being able to integrate Lua scripting in Pulp would be great.

More of a variety of "game modes" - or support for things that aren't tile-based. Maybe adding a couple of templates for different project types would make it more viable for beginners.

I know it's got a lot of cool potential!!! It's just hard to get creative if you're already a novice.
More flexible import/export system
Isometric tiles features, point and click features
A more robust sprite system for larger assets. It feels kind of hacky to code them in now.
